posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked: My team recently tasked me with giving the robot self-positioning capabilities using Limelight, but I have no idea how to do it or the theory behind it, let alone the syntax, since I‚Äôm just getting started in FRC programming. I wonder if anyone could do me a favor and explain it to me or send me some test code so I can first understand how it works.

posts.name: Patrick McNaughton
posts.cooked:
I would take a look at the documentation first

* The Limelight Smart Camera was designed to make robotic perception as easy and reliable as possible without sacrificing raw performance. The Limelight platform is easy enough for complete beginners, and powerful enough for professionals.

Additionally, I found this talk very useful when first learning about computer vision.

This was pre apriltags in frc, but still has a lot of interesting stuff.

link_counts.title: Limelight Zero-Code Robotic Perception | Limelight Documentation

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked: Here‚Äôs one that‚Äôs more contemporary and talks through the theory behind it.  If you like it, I highly recommend perusing all of @jonahb55 posts on CD .

posts.name: Koller Koller Kroeff
posts.cooked:
adriel_derof4735:

My team recently tasked me with giving the robot self-positioning capabilities using Limelight, but I have no idea how to do it or the theory behind it, let alone the syntax, since I‚Äôm just getting started in FRC programming. I wonder if anyone could do me a favor and explain it to me or send me some test code so I can first understand how it works.

Hi! So, when a robot ‚Äúself-positions‚Äù on the field, the basic idea is that it combines sensor data with a mathematical model of the field. For example, a Limelight camera can detect AprilTags (special fiducial markers placed on the field). Each AprilTag has a known position in the official field map. When the robot sees a tag, it can calculate its own distance and angle relative to that tag.

By combining this with the robot‚Äôs own heading sensor (usually a gyro), the system can estimate the robot‚Äôs exact position and orientation, called its pose (x, y, and angle) on the field.

This is the tutorial i made for the easiest way that is highly effective to do auto alignment with limelight

From zero to auto align to reef tutorial how to simply auto align to the reef Programming

From zero to auto align to reef tutorial how to simply auto align to the reef Programming

link_counts.title: From zero to auto align to reef tutorial how to simply auto align to the reef

posts.cooked: Not sure the state of your capabilities, etc.  But a good early goal would be to have a dashboard up with a field widget and drive your robot around and see if it moves.  Second goal‚Ä¶. Does the real robot match the widget. I would make sure all of that is working before you tackle adding vision.

posts.name: Adriel
posts.cooked: As far as I know, I already have the field widget and I can more or less move it around. I can also connect the robot to my computer and move it, since the robot already has the swerve and odometry movements programmed.
